cmCourseInfo.description: Principles and concepts of evolution and ecology related to origins of adaptation and biodiversity. Mechanisms and processes driving biological diversification illustrated from various perspectives using empirical and theoretical approaches. Topics include: genetic diversity, natural selection, speciation, physiological, population, and community ecology, maintenance of species diversity, conservation, species extinction, global environmental change, and invasion biology. A lab coat is required and the cost is approximately $16 if students wish to purchase it through the Department. (Lab Materials Fee: $25)
cmCourseInfo.title: Adaptation and Biodiversity
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Grade 12 Biology or equivalent. Students without high school Biology must consult the BIO120 Office (bio120@utoronto.ca)

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Lectures will begin on Tuesday, May 8, from 10:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. Practicals begin the first week of classes (i.e. students in P0101 meet 1:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. on Tuesday, May 8). Please purchase the lab manual from the U of T Bookstore and read Chapter 1 and 6 before your first lab. Labs will be held in RW102, RW104, and RW130. Laboratory enrolment can be done on SWS until 4pm on Thursday, May 3. As of May 7, laboratory enrolment and changes can ONLY be done by the BIO120 Office; see the course site on the U of T Portal for details (www.portal.utoronto.ca). For more information, please email bio120@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: One of the goals of modern biology is to understand how the basic building blocks of life give rise to biological form and function. This course provides students with a common lexicon to understand the key principles and concepts in molecular and cell biology, with a focus on how the building blocks of life lead to functioning cells. (Lab Materials Fee: $10). Lab coat and safety glasses are required for use in laboratories; students are responsible for purchasing these items (approximate cost is $25).
cmCourseInfo.title: Molecular and Cell Biology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SBI4U and SCH4U (Grade 12 University Preparation Biology and Chemistry) or permission of department. Please contact bio130@utoronto.ca for more information.

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Labs begin the first week of class. Last day to enroll in a lab is end of day June 29th. All labs are on Thursdays from 1-4 pm. You can find out what lab group (e.g., P0201A) and room you are in by logging into Portal and looking under the 'My Grades' section. The lab manual can be purchased at the UofT Bookstore and all course information will be available on the course website on Portal. For more information, please contact bio130@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: The genome is the "book of life," providing instructions to construct an organism. This course introduces genome biology and explores how the building blocks of life are networked into functioning organisms. We will investigate how cells perceive internal and external cues, how gene expression is shaped by this perception, and how these events give rise to tissues, organs, and whole organisms. (Lab Materials Fee: $20). Lab coat and safety glasses are required for use in laboratories; students are responsible for purchasing these items (approximate cost is $25).
cmCourseInfo.title: From Genes to Organisms
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: BIO240H1, BIO241H1, BIO250Y1, BIO255H1, BIO255Y1. Students who have only completed one of BIO240H1 or BIO241H1 can take BIO230H1 for credit.

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Labs begin the first week of class. Enrollment in labs close end of day on May 4th after which any lab changes will be done in RW206A on Monday, May 7th from 1:00 to 3:00 p.m ONLY. You can find out what section and group (e.g., P0101A) you are in by logging into Portal and looking under the 'My Grades' section. The lab manual can be purchased at the UofT Bookstore and all course information will be available on the course website on Portal. For more information, please contact bio230@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: The main ideas of physiology and the contribution of experimentation to our understanding of life processes. Uses examples from throughout the animal kingdom, and includes the physiology of homeostasis and the endocrine system. Accompanying laboratories reinforce the concepts introduced in lecture and teach relevant techniques. (Lab Materials Fee: $10).
cmCourseInfo.title: Animal Physiology I

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Labs begin the first week of class. Laboratory enrolment can be done on ACORN until the evening of Wednesday, May 2nd. After this date, late lab enrolment or lab changes must be done as soon as possible in the BIO270/271 office in RW 424E or contact Peggy Salmon at peggy.salmon@utoronto.ca. Lab manual and all course information are available on the U of T Portal course website.

cmCourseInfo.description: The main ideas of physiology and the contribution of experimentation to our understanding of life processes. Uses examples from throughout the animal kingdom, and includes the physiology of the nervous and cardiorespiratory systems. Accompanying laboratories reinforce the concepts introduced in lecture and teach relevant techniques. (Lab Materials Fee: $10).
cmCourseInfo.title: Animal Physiology II
